content:
The last part of the proof of Lemma 7.7.3 does not make sense.

image.png

In the first line of equations the tile u\mathfrak uu is bound to a sum, but then it becomes free in the second line. What was actually intended? What tile does the free u\mathfrak uu actually refer to?
(progress at fpvandoorn/carleson#374)

You can replace the second line by

â‰¤âˆ«Xmaxâ¡uâˆˆUjâˆ£S2,ug1(y)âˆ£2â€‰dÎ¼(y)=maxâ¡uâˆˆUjâˆ¥S2,ug1âˆ¥22â€‰.\le \int_X \max_{u \in U_j}|S_{2,u}g_1(y)|^2 \, \mathrm{d}\mu(y) = \max_{u \in U_j}\|S_{2,u} g_1\|_2^2\,.â‰¤âˆ«Xâ€‹uâˆˆUjâ€‹maxâ€‹âˆ£S2,uâ€‹g1â€‹(y)âˆ£2dÎ¼(y)=uâˆˆUjâ€‹maxâ€‹âˆ¥S2,uâ€‹g1â€‹âˆ¥22â€‹.

Similarly for the next displayed equation.
This is a finite maximum, and you can still use Lemma 7.4.3 to finish the proof.
Oh wait, that equality doesn't hold... Let me ask Lars.

I just pushed a fix to the blueprint (with Lars' help). This was a genuine but fixable mistake in the proof of this lemma. Note: the last 2 equations before your screenshot also got changed, by keeping the indicator functions around the gig_igiâ€‹.

Something is still wrong with the proof. I can get to

_ = âˆ‘ u with u âˆˆ rowDecomp t j, âˆ‘ u' with u' âˆˆ rowDecomp t j',
        â€–âˆ« x, (ğ“˜ u : Set X).indicator (adjointCarlesonSum (t u) ((ğ“˜ u : Set X).indicator fâ‚) Â·) x *
        conj ((ğ“˜ u' : Set X).indicator (adjointCarlesonSum (t u') ((ğ“˜ u' : Set X).indicator fâ‚‚) Â·) x)â€–â‚‘

but I cannot remove the outer indicators and say that this is less than

_ â‰¤ âˆ‘ u with u âˆˆ rowDecomp t j, âˆ‘ u' with u' âˆˆ rowDecomp t j',
        â€–âˆ« x, adjointCarlesonSum (t u) ((ğ“˜ u : Set X).indicator fâ‚) x *
        conj (adjointCarlesonSum (t u') ((ğ“˜ u' : Set X).indicator fâ‚‚) x)â€–â‚‘

because these are indicators on complex numbers, which have no ordering. Or am I missing something obvious?

The norm should be inside the integral, not outside it, in the definition of the L^2-norm. And then you have a nonnegative integrand, so increasing the integration domain will only increase the value of the integral.
(and for formalisation that means you want to use the Lebesgue integral)
The blueprint uses the Bochner (over complexes) integral for the statement of Lemma 7.7.3 and its predecessor lemmas. Is it wrong then?

lemma row_correlation (hjj' : j < j') (hj' : j' < 2 ^ n)
    (hfâ‚ : BoundedCompactSupport fâ‚) (h3fâ‚ : âˆ€ x, â€–fâ‚ xâ€– â‰¤ G.indicator 1 x)
    (hfâ‚‚ : BoundedCompactSupport fâ‚‚) (h3fâ‚‚ : âˆ€ x, â€–fâ‚‚ xâ€– â‰¤ G.indicator 1 x) :
    â€–âˆ« x, (âˆ‘ u âˆˆ {p | p âˆˆ rowDecomp t j}, adjointCarlesonSum (t u) fâ‚ x) *
    (âˆ‘ u âˆˆ {p | p âˆˆ rowDecomp t j'}, adjointCarlesonSum (t u) fâ‚‚ x)â€–â‚Š â‰¤
    C7_7_3 a n * eLpNorm fâ‚ 2 volume * eLpNorm fâ‚‚ 2 volume := by

If the norm is outside an integral (of - say - complex-valued functions): use the Bochner integral. If it's inside the integral, use the Lebesgue integral. You should switch between the two when you move the integral inside.
"moving the norm inside the integral" is docs#MeasureTheory.enorm_integral_le_lintegral_enorm
So the moment you apply Lemma 7.4.4 in the proof of Lemma 7.7.3 you should switch from the Bochner integral to the Lebesgue integral (or L^p-norm, which is defined in terms of the Lebesgue integral)

Floris van Doorn said:

"moving the norm inside the integral" is docs#MeasureTheory.enorm_integral_le_lintegral_enorm

But I cannot switch back from Lebesgue to Bochner â€“ that's an inequality, not an equality â€“ and correlation_separated_trees is set in terms of Bochner

lemma correlation_separated_trees (huâ‚ : uâ‚ âˆˆ t) (huâ‚‚ : uâ‚‚ âˆˆ t) (hu : uâ‚ â‰  uâ‚‚)
    (hgâ‚ : BoundedCompactSupport gâ‚) (hgâ‚‚ : BoundedCompactSupport gâ‚‚) :
    â€–âˆ« x, adjointCarlesonSum (t uâ‚) gâ‚ x * conj (adjointCarlesonSum (t uâ‚‚) gâ‚‚ x)â€–â‚Š â‰¤
    C7_4_4 a n *
    eLpNorm
      ((ğ“˜ uâ‚ âˆ© ğ“˜ uâ‚‚ : Set X).indicator (adjointBoundaryOperator t uâ‚ gâ‚) Â·) 2 volume *
    eLpNorm
      ((ğ“˜ uâ‚ âˆ© ğ“˜ uâ‚‚ : Set X).indicator (adjointBoundaryOperator t uâ‚‚ gâ‚‚) Â·) 2 volume := by

I cannot easily adapt correlation_separated_trees to use Lebesgue either for the same reason, because âˆ«â» x, â€–adjointCarlesonSum (t uâ‚) gâ‚ x * conj (adjointCarlesonSum (t uâ‚‚) gâ‚‚ x)â€–â‚‘ is greater than or equal to the LHS, not less than or equal

Yes, so you start your calculation with the LHS of Lemma 7.7.3, using the Bochner integral, do some estimations with the Bochner integral until you apply Lemma 7.4.4, whose LHS has the Bochner integral, and then the RHS doesn't have a Bochner integral anymore. All further calculations happen using the Lebesgue integral.
So you shouldn't ever have to switch back from Lebesgue to Bochner, and the statement of correlation_separated_trees should also not be changed.

Or schematically:

LHSÂ ofÂ 7.7.3â‰¤(expressionsÂ involvingÂ theÂ BochnerÂ integral)â‰¤(expressionsÂ involvingÂ theÂ LebesgueÂ integralÂ orÂ Lp-norms)â‰¤RHSÂ ofÂ 7.7.3\text{LHS of 7.7.3} \le \text{(expressions involving the Bochner integral)} \le \text{(expressions involving the Lebesgue integral or $L^p$-norms)} \le \text{RHS of 7.7.3}LHSÂ ofÂ 7.7.3â‰¤(expressionsÂ involvingÂ theÂ BochnerÂ integral)â‰¤(expressionsÂ involvingÂ theÂ LebesgueÂ integralÂ orÂ Lp-norms)â‰¤RHSÂ ofÂ 7.7.3

EDIT: Zulip doesn't support \stackrel: the middle inequality is applying Lemma 7.4.4.

I do not know whether to apply Lemma 7.4.1 (introducing the indicators) before or after applying Lemma 7.4.4. Regarding my PR as it is now, if I apply 7.4.1 before 7.4.4, I get the problem I mentioned above, but were I to apply it after, I don't see how to bound eLpNorm ((ğ“˜ u âˆ© ğ“˜ u' : Set X).indicator (adjointBoundaryOperator t u fâ‚) Â·) 2 volume by eLpNorm ((ğ“˜ u âˆ© ğ“˜ u' : Set X).indicator (adjointBoundaryOperator t u ((ğ“˜ u : Set X).indicator fâ‚)) Â·) 2 volume

My whole point is that the equation just before (7.7.5) should have extra indicator functions outside the TT(u)âˆ—gT_{\mathfrak T(\mathfrak u)}^*gTT(u)âˆ—â€‹g's, but then that is not a form on which I can apply Lemma 7.4.4

It should read as
âˆ‘uâˆˆUjâˆ‘uâ€²âˆˆUjâ€²âˆ£âˆ«1I(u)1I(uâ€²)TTj(u)âˆ—(1I(u)g1)TTjâ€²(uâ€²)âˆ—(1I(uâ€²)g2)â€¾â€‰dÎ¼âˆ£\sum _{{\mathfrak u}\in {\mathfrak U}_j} \sum _{{\mathfrak u}' \in {\mathfrak U}_{j'}} \left| \int \mathbf{1}_{{\mathcal{I}}({\mathfrak u})} \mathbf{1}_{{\mathcal{I}}({\mathfrak u'})} T^*_{{\mathfrak T}_j({\mathfrak u})} (\mathbf{1}_{{\mathcal{I}}({\mathfrak u})} g_1) \overline{T^*_{{\mathfrak T}_{j'}({\mathfrak u}')} (\mathbf{1}_{{\mathcal{I}}({\mathfrak u}')} g_2)} \, \mathrm{d}\mu \right|âˆ‘uâˆˆUjâ€‹â€‹âˆ‘uâ€²âˆˆUjâ€²â€‹â€‹â€‹âˆ«1I(u)â€‹1I(uâ€²)â€‹TTjâ€‹(u)âˆ—â€‹(1I(u)â€‹g1â€‹)TTjâ€²â€‹(uâ€²)âˆ—â€‹(1I(uâ€²)â€‹g2â€‹)â€‹dÎ¼â€‹
Wait a minuteâ€¦ I think I have it

I was missing the following lemma not explicitly stated in the blueprint

/-- A partially applied variant of `adjoint_tile_support2_sum`, used to prove Lemma 7.7.3. -/
lemma adjoint_tile_support2_sum_partial (hu : u âˆˆ t) :
    adjointCarlesonSum (t u) f = (adjointCarlesonSum (t u) ((ğ“˜ u : Set X).indicator f)) := by
  unfold adjointCarlesonSum
  ext x; simp only [Finset.sum_apply]; congr! 1 with p mp
  simp_rw [Finset.mem_filter, Finset.mem_univ, true_and] at mp
  rw [â† adjoint_eq_adjoint_indicator (E_subset_ğ“˜.trans (t.smul_four_le hu mp).1.1)]

Yes, that's right. It's the first step of the proof of Lemma 7.4.1, which is being used here.
Lemma 7.4.1 is basically just a non-standard way of saying Tpâˆ—(g)T_p^*(g)Tpâˆ—â€‹(g) only depends in the values of ggg in I(u)I(u)I(u) and its support is also a subset of I(u)I(u)I(u).
@Floris van Doorn the proof's done
Jeremy Tan has marked this topic as resolved.
